awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Constraining Paired Air-Water Temperature Models' Efficacy In Head and Intermediate Watersheds With Groundwater and Bedrock Assessment and Multi-Decade Temperature Records
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change increases atmospheric temperatures, which alters temperature patterns in groundwater and streams and results in reduced water quality and ecological diversity. In parts of the eastern United States, like West Virginia, climate has already warmed 0.5º – 1.0º F over the last century and temperatures are expected to rise another 3º – 4º F by the year 2100, further warming stream and shallow groundwater temperatures and affecting the organisms that live there. Stream temperature patterns provide insight into the vulnerability of these streams and watersheds to warming temperatures. However, current models do not fully account for temperature changes caused by interactions of water on the surface and underground. Model predictions of ground and surface water temperatures in a changing climate must be informed by the factors that influence thermal signals, including climate, geology, hydrology, land use, and land cover. Data show stream temperature changes in response to changing climate are likely driven (in part) by changes in relative contributions and temperatures of discharging groundwater. The Fernow Experimental Forest (FEF) in West Virginia has been recording temperature data in at least ten headwater watersheds since 1958. Using the FEF as a well-controlled outdoor laboratory to study these temperature patterns, Riddell will generate improved models and better knowledge of these systems. Improved models can be used to estimate watershed responses to drought or high intensity precipitation events, and associated disasters such as flooding. This work will directly impact middle and high school high school students in WV through collaboration with the National Youth Science Foundation (NYSF). This proposed work is in the Monongahela National Forest where the National Youth Science Foundation has hosted its National Youth Science Camp since 1963. The FEF is close to the camp and the newly purchased National Youth Science Center (NYSCenter) in Davis, WV. During this project, collaboration with NYSF staff will result in the installation of a stream gage monitoring station on the Blackwater River, which is adjacent to the NYSCenter to deliver hydrology education to middle and high school students in WV. This collaboration will support the NYSF mission to build and maintain student interest in STEM fields and promote high school retention rates and the pursuance of post-secondary STEM education.

Climate change is increasing atmospheric temperatures which alters thermal patterns in groundwater and streams, resulting in reduced water quality and ecological diversity. Thermal regimes in surface waters are highly influenced by groundwater and its connectivity to the surface, which may be discerned by comparing air and stream temperature records. Paired air-water temperature analysis via sine wave regression is a way to characterize the relationship between air temperature and surface water temperature to elucidate the groundwater contributions to  watershed hydraulics, cold-water habitat refugia, and groundwater temperature response to climate change. Recent research has focused on modeling annual paired-air/water temperature signals to assess the role of groundwater in propagating air temperature to stream water from sub-watershed to continental scales. Results of these sine regression studies are focused on determining the inputs of groundwater to surface water and the eventual response of surface water to climate change by comparing the amplitude ratios (sine curve peak height) and phase lag signals (time between peaks) of air and water temperature records. Deeper groundwater signatures show little variation in annual temperature and have ambiguous amplitude ratio and phase lag whereas shallow groundwater signatures show high amplitude ratios and measurable phase lag on the order of days. However, current models do not fully account for groundwater – surface water interactions that influence stream temperatures. These processes are governed by aquifer characteristics such as aquifer thickness, porosity, hydraulic conductivity, and bedrock type and depth. This study will utilize the Fernow Experimental Forest in WV to improve thermal stream model efficacy in small and intermediate watersheds by collecting new groundwater temperature measurements, assessing the influence of differing bedrock geology in the same watershed, and exploring the efficacy of these models in hydrologically connected, nested watersheds and in watersheds in which air and stream temperature records exist across multiple decades. This study will advance the knowledge of groundwater contributions to headwater watersheds and intermediate watersheds into which they discharge and to the vulnerability of these watersheds to climate change. The current models (sine regression) being applied to large, continental size watersheds recognize the importance of local hydrogeology and geology on groundwater behavior and the subsequent effects on surface stream temperature patterns. However, no study has yet to intensively characterize the surface hydrology, hydrogeology, and bedrock geology of small watersheds and the contribution of all these factors on stream temperature patterns. This study will fill that gap and highlight the importance of characterizing the subsurface when making predictions about the surface. 

This project is jointly funded by the Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship program, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) and the Hydrologic Sciences program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to use a simple statistical model to evaluate air and water temperature patterns in the Fernow Experimental Forest, WV, USA. The primary watershed in this forest is the Elklick Run watershed, which is part of the larger Cheat River watershed, a major watershed in eastern and northern WV. Elklick Run bisects the Fernow generally north-to-south- and receives discharge from small tributary streams to the east and west. The tributary streams to the west of Elklick Run have been delineated into smaller watersheds and subjected to various forestry management practices over the last ~60 years like clear cutting, select cutting, herbicide treatments, and others. Water quality has also been monitored in these watersheds including discharge, pH, temperature, and dissolved chemical constituents like calcium, magnesium, nitrates, and sulfates. These watersheds are underlain by sandstone bedrock. The tributaries to the east of Elklick Run have not been previously monitored for these parameters and are also underlain by layers of sandstone, shale, siltstones, and limestones.

The historical data from the western watersheds was subjected to statistical analysis to compare surface water temperatures to air temperatures and assess how different forestry management practices affect water temperature. Data were also compared to historical air temperatures for North America. Overall, air temperatures in the Fernow have shown a statistical increase since 1952 and are approaching the 20th-century average for North America of 11.1 C. Water temperatures in the Fernow are also increasing as air temperatures are increasing. Statistical analysis of air and water temperatures showed that water temperatures in the Fernow are highly responsive to air temperatures but do experience a seasonal lag in peak temperatures of 8 to 35 days. While stream temperatures never rise as high as air temperatures, they do exhibit a distinct seasonal pattern of warmer temperatures in summer months and cooler temperatures in winter months. Watersheds subjected to forestry management techniques do show a deviation from expected stream temperature and these deviations differ among watersheds. This suggests that forestry management technique does affect stream water temperatures.

Underlying geology may also influence stream water temperatures due to contributions from groundwater into the streams (Figure 4). To begin to assess this difference, air and water temperature sensors were installed throughout the western tributaries to Elklick Run at up and downstream locations as well as throughout the eastern tributaries in areas where there is a geologic transition. Data collection and analysis at these locations is ongoing. A technique for measuring and calculating the amount of water being discharged from these streams is also being developed. Four shallow groundwater wells were also installed to monitor the temperature and depth of the shallowest groundwater throughout the Fernow. This work also resulted in the publication of a peer-reviewed, publicly available field guide, Hydrology and Geology of the Fernow Experimental Forest, which describes the regional geology and hydrology of the Fernow. Anyone with a basic to professional understanding of geology can use this field guide.

The results of this project show that even small streams are increasing in temperature as the climate warms. Warming headwaters that are being discharged into larger rivers and streams may disrupt the temperature balance necessary for the spawning and breeding of certain fish and invertebrate species. This has implications for the ecological balance of these environments and how conservation scientists may work to develop mitigation and remediation techniques in such environments. The interdisciplinary nature of this work has implications for how foresters, ecologists, geologists, and water scientists can use data from each discipline to understand climate disruption in any environment.
